metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.

content.text: AngularJS Scope
The scope is the binding part between the HTML (view) and the JavaScript (controller).
content.html: The scope is the binding part between the HTML (view) and the JavaScript (controller).

content.text: The scope is an object with the available properties and methods.
content.html: The scope is an object with the available properties and methods.

content.text: The scope is available for both the view and the controller.
content.html: The scope is available for both the view and the controller.

content.text: How to Use the Scope?
When you make a controller in AngularJS, you pass the $scope object as an argument:
content.html: When you make a controller in AngularJS, you pass the $scope object as an argument:

content.code_html:
<div ng-app="myApp" ng-controller="myCtrl">

<h1>{{carname}}</h1>

</div>

<script>
var app = angular.module('myApp', []);

app.controller('myCtrl', function($scope) {
  $scope.carname = "Volvo";
});
</script>

content.text: When adding properties to the $scope object in the controller, the view (HTML) gets access to these properties.
content.html: When adding properties to the $scope object in the controller, the view (HTML) gets access to these properties.

content.text: In the view, you do not use the prefix $scope , you just refer to a property name, like {{carname}} .
content.html: In the view, you do not use the prefix $scope, you just refer to a property name, like {{carname}}.

content.text: Understanding the Scope
If we consider an AngularJS application to consist of:
content.html: If we consider an AngularJS application to consist of:

content.text: Then the scope is the Model.
The scope is a JavaScript object with properties and methods, which are available for both the view and the controller.
content.html: The scope is a JavaScript object with properties and methods, which are available for both the view and the controller.

content.code_html:
<div ng-app="myApp" ng-controller="myCtrl">

<input ng-model="name">

<h1>My name is {{name}}</h1>

</div>

<script>
var app = angular.module('myApp', []);

app.controller('myCtrl', function($scope) {
  $scope.name = "John Doe";
});
</script>

content.text: Know Your Scope
It is important to know which scope you are dealing with, at any time.
content.html: It is important to know which scope you are dealing with, at any time.

content.text: In the two examples above there is only one scope, so knowing your scope is not an issue, but for larger applications there can be sections in the HTML DOM which can only access certain scopes.
content.html: In the two examples above there is only one scope, so knowing your scope is not an issue, but for larger applications there can be sections in the HTML DOM which can only access certain scopes.

content.code_html:
<div ng-app="myApp" ng-controller="myCtrl">

<ul>
  <li ng-repeat="x in names">{{x}}</li>
</ul>

</div>

<script>
var app = angular.module('myApp', []);

app.controller('myCtrl', function($scope) {
  $scope.names = ["Emil", "Tobias", "Linus"];
});
</script>

content.text: Each <li> element has access to the current repetition object, in this case a string, which is referred to by using x .
content.html: Each <li> element has access to the current repetition object, in this case a string, which is referred to by using x.

content.text: Root Scope
All applications have a $rootScope which is the scope created on the HTML element that contains the ng-app directive.
content.html: All applications have a $rootScope which is the scope created on the HTML element that contains the ng-app directive.

content.text: The rootScope is available in the entire application.
content.html: The rootScope is available in the entire application.

content.text: If a variable has the same name in both the current scope and in the rootScope, the application uses the one in the current scope.
content.html: If a variable has the same name in both the current scope and in the rootScope, the application uses the one in the current scope.

content.code_html:
<body ng-app="myApp">

<p>The rootScope's favorite color:</p>
<h1>{{color}}</h1>

<div ng-controller="myCtrl">
  <p>The scope of the controller's favorite color:</p>
  <h1>{{color}}</h1>
</div>

<p>The rootScope's favorite color is still:</p>
<h1>{{color}}</h1>

<script>
var app = angular.module('myApp', []);
app.run(function($rootScope) {
  $rootScope.color = 'blue';
});
app.controller('myCtrl', function($scope) {
  $scope.color = "red";
});
</script>
</body>
